When you see colors what you see is the frequency that is emitted by the body.  All bodies will absorb and emit radiation, but it depends on the nature of the body what frequencies it will absorb/admit.  In the case of the pigment black, it absorbs all frequency and emits none, hence you see black (absence of color or light).  You see red when the body emits frequencies in the red spectrum, yellow with frequencies in the yellow spectrum and so on.  You see white when the body emits all freqs.

What started as a low entropy system (20 molecules neatly placed near each other) has, after a million collisions, become a seemingly random arrangement of particles all moving in different directions. Since it is hard to catalog the instantaneous position and velocity of all the particles simultaneously, we say the system has high entropy. This isn't because the equations of motion suddenly spit out crazy numbers, it is because the system is sensitive to initial conditions.

Say you have 20 nitrogen molecules all very close together in a spherical enclosure. You then give the group of molecules a push toward one of the walls of the enclosure. They all move according to Newton's equations for motion, and bounce off the wall with perfect elasticity. However, they all take diverging paths because each one hits the curved wall in a slightly different place. This is sensitivity to initial conditions (in this case, position), and each collision magnifies the effect.

I am flattered that you mention Einstein and me in the same sentence (despite the obvious disparity in stature--I cannot complain). 
Anyway, chaos does not kill everything. It is actually a reasonable theoretical basis for the second law of thermodynamics, which states that thermodynamic systems tend to become more disordered as time goes on (their "entropy" increases). Entropy is a measure of the amount of information that is "hidden". This of course is subjective to the quality of perception.

About mass being a certain speed of vibration, consider the relationship P = hv/c [de Broglie's equation: momentum of a photon is proportional to its frequency, and is scaled by the Planck constant / the speed of light] You see that as a photon's frequency increases, its momentum increases. By Newton's P = mv, momentum is increased by increasing either speed or mass. Since a photon always travels at c, it's apparent "mass" increases with frequency, i.e. faster vibration = higher mass [energy].
